sidebar.title: OpenStack upstream features that are enabled by default in &kw-hos-phrase;
sidebar.para: The following supported Keystone features are enabled by default in the &kw-hos-phrase; release.

row.entry: Note: API support only. No CLI/UI support

sidebar.para: To allow for the practice of hierarchical permissions in user roles, this feature enables roles to be linked in such a way that they function as a hierarchy with role inheritance.
When a user is assigned a superior role, the user will also be assigned all roles implied by any subordinate roles. The hierarchy of the assigned roles will be expanded when issuing the user a token.

This feature extends the principle of implied roles to include a set of roles that are specific to a domain. At the time a token is issued, the domain-specific roles are not included in the token, however, the roles that they map to are.

sidebar.title: OpenStack upstream features that are disabled by default in &kw-hos-phrase;
sidebar.para: The following is a list of features which are fully supported in the &kw-hos-phrase; release, but are disabled by default. Customers can run a playbook to enable the features.

row.entry: Support multiple LDAP backends via per-domain configuration
Experimental feature in Mitaka release. Note: there are still pending bugs and broken tempest tests.
Domain specific configuration options can be stored in SQL instead of configuration files, using the new REST APIs.

para.emphasis: Multiple LDAP backends for each domain

sidebar.para: This feature allows identity backends to be configured on a domain-by-domain basis. Domains will be capable of having their own exclusive LDAP service (or multiple services). A single LDAP service can also serve multiple domains, with each domain in a separate subtree.
To implement this feature, individual domains will require domain-specific configuration files. Domains that do not implement this feature will continue to share a common backend driver.
This feature enables the Keystone service to provide federated identity services through a token-based single sign-on page. This feature is disabled by default, as it requires explicit configuration.

This feature enables separate Keystone instances to federate identities among the instances, offering inter-cloud authorization. This feature is disabled by default, as it requires explicit configuration.
Provides tokens in the fernet format. This is an experimental feature and is disabled by default.
Using the new REST APIs, domain-specific configuration options can be stored in a SQL database instead of in configuration files.

title.emphasis: OpenStack upstream features that have been specifically disabled in &kw-hos-phrase;

sidebar.para: The following is a list of extensions which are disabled by default in &kw-hos-phrase;, according to Keystone policy.

row.entry: This extension was implemented by HP to facilitate service activation. However, due to lack of enforcement at the service side, this feature is only half effective right now.

This extension was intended to facilitate policy (policy.json) management and enforcement. This feature is useless right now due to lack of the needed middleware to utilize the policy files stored in Keystone.
Complexity in workflow. Lack of adoption. Its alternative, Keystone Trust, is enabled by default. HEAT is using Keystone Trust.
For PKI token only and PKI token is disabled by default due to usability concerns.

PKI token is disabled by default due to usability concerns.
